contentrichtext.text: {{other uses|Godefroy Cavaignac (disambiguation)}} {{multiple issues| {{One source|date=February 2012}} {{No footnotes|date=February 2012}} }} [[File:Jacques Marie Eugène Godefroy Cavaignac.jpg|thumb|Jacques Marie Eugène Godefroy Cavaignac]] '''Jacques Marie Eugène Godefroy Cavaignac''' (May 21, 1853 – September 25, 1905), known as Godefroy Cavaignac, [[France|French]] [[politician]], was born in [[Paris, France|Paris]]. He was the son of [[Louis Eugène Cavaignac]]. He made public profession of his republican principles as a schoolboy at the [[Lycée Charlemagne]] by refusing in 1867 to receive a prize at the [[University of Paris|Sorbonne]] from the hand of the [[Napoleon Eugene, Prince Imperial|prince imperial]]. ==Under the Third Republic== {{further|French Third Republic}} Godefroy Cavaignac received the military medal for service in the [[Franco-Prussian War]], and in 1872 entered the [[École Polytechnique]]. He served as a civil engineer in [[Angoulême]] until 1881, when he became master of requests in the [[Council of State (France)|Council of State]]. In the next year he was elected deputy for the ''[[arrondissement in France|arrondissement]]'' of [[Saint-Calais]] ([[Sarthe]]) in the republican interest. In 1885-1886 he was under-secretary for war in the [[Henri Brisson]] ministry, and he served in the cabinet of [[Émile Loubet]] (1892) as [[List of Naval Ministers of France|Minister of Marine and of the Colonies]]. He had exchanged his [[Opportunist Republicans|moderate republicanism]] for [[Radical-Socialist Party|radical]] views before he became [[List of Defense Ministers of France|War Minister]] in the cabinet of [[Léon Bourgeois]] (November 1, 1895 to April 29, 1896). He was again Minister of War in the Brisson cabinet from June 28, 1898 to September 5, 1898. In July 1898, he read in the chamber a document, which definitely incriminated [[Alfred Dreyfus|Captain Alfred Dreyfus]]. On August 30, however, he stated that this had been discovered to be a forgery by [[Hubert-Joseph Henry|Colonel Henry]], but he refused to concur with his colleagues in a revision of the [[Dreyfus Affair|Dreyfus prosecution]], which was the logical outcome of his own exposure of the forgery. Resigning his portfolio, he continued to declare his conviction of Dreyfus's guilt, and joined the Nationalist group in the chamber, of which he became one of the leaders. (He is portrayed in precisely the opposite way in the 1937 film ''[[The Life of Emile Zola]]'', in which he is depicted as the person who finally discovers the truth and demands the resignation of all those responsible for incriminating Dreyfus.) He also was an energetic supporter of the [[Ligue de la Patrie Française]]. In 1899 Cavaignac was an unsuccessful candidate for the Presidency of the Republic. He had announced his intention of retiring from political life when he died at his country-seat near [[Flée, Sarthe|Flée]] (Sarthe) on September 25, 1905. ==Works== He wrote an important book on the ''Formation de la Prusse contemporaine'' (2 vols., 1891–1898), dealing with the [[Napoleonic Wars|events of 1806–1813]]. ==See also== *[[History of France in the nineteenth century]] *[[Opportunist Republicans]] *[[Radical-Socialist Party]] *[[History of the French Left]] *[[Dreyfus Affair]] ==References== *{{1911}} {{Persondata |NAME=Cavaignac, Jacques Marie Eugène Godefroy |ALTERNATIVE NAMES= |SHORT DESCRIPTION=[[France|French]] politician |DATE OF BIRTH=May 21, 1853 |PLACE OF BIRTH=[[Paris]] |DATE OF DEATH=September 25, 1905 |PLACE OF DEATH=[[Flée, Sarthe|Flée]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cavaignac, Jacques Marie Eugene Godefroy}} [[Category:1853 births]] [[Category:1905 deaths]] [[Category:Politicians from Paris]] [[Category:French military personnel of the Franco-Prussian War]] [[Category:Ministers of Marine and the Colonies]] [[Category:French Ministers of Colonies]] [[Category:People associated with the Dreyfus Affair]] [[Category:Burials at Montmartre Cemetery]]
